instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ASD Failed on VP0R
threads.message:
Small liquid damage near SMC.
It works but ASD test failed on VP0R.

<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>/2 0.054V (sometimes there is even 0.215V but slowly dropping)
<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>/3 0.010V
<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>/4 8.15V
<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>/5 7.03V
<TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>/6 6.10V

Replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR> just in case but still <SIGNAL>SMC_SENSOR_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> is low.
I see that line coming from SMC...

Any idea how to solve that?
Thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ASD Failed on VP0R
threads.message: Check <CHIP>U8050</CHIP> area for water damage, other than that, crap/corrosion under SMC, apply some flux to SMC and heat, about 170Â°C.......

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ASD Failed on VP0R
threads.message: <CHIP>U8050</CHIP> clean, used flux on SMC... still same issue - just dont tell me SMC needs to be replaced :D

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ASD Failed on VP0R
threads.message:
ok i'll stay quiet...... but you know what to do...;);)

Maybe you could try reballing but is the same shit than replace....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ASD Failed on VP0R
threads.message: Spotted a pre-balled on eBay recently.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> ASD Failed on VP0R
threads.message: What has <CHIP>U8050</CHIP> to do with this? Problem will be corrosion on <TRANSISTOR>Q5500</TRANSISTOR>.
